message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The fact that participants with G6PD deficiency were excluded suggests that G6PD deficiency is not the cause of the absence of infection. Among the remaining options, only Glutamic acid substitution in the β-globin chain is associated with resistance to malaria. This substitution results in sickle cell hemoglobin, which confers resistance to malaria by impairing the parasite's survival in red blood cells.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The fact that participants with G6PD deficiency were excluded from the study suggests that the absence of infection is not related to this condition. Among the other options, only a glutamic acid substitution in the β-globin chain can be related to protection against malaria infection, known as sickle cell trait.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. G6PD deficiency is excluded from the study, which suggests that the absence of infection in the subset is not related to G6PD deficiency. Among the other options, only the glutamic acid substitution in the β-globin chain is known to protect against malaria infection. This is due to the fact that the mutation leads to the formation of abnormal hemoglobin (HbS), which causes sickling of red blood cells and limits the ability of Plasmodium to invade and replicate within them, thus providing some level of protection against the disease.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The fact that participants with G6PD deficiency were excluded suggests that this group may have a protective effect against malaria. Among the options, only (D) Glutamic acid substitution in the β-globin chain is associated with sickle cell anemia, which is known to confer resistance to malaria.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. G6PD deficiency is excluded from the study, so we can eliminate option A as there is no mention of ankyrin protein. Option B is also irrelevant as it causes a different disease (X-linked sideroblastic anemia). Option C is not relevant to malaria infection. Glutamic acid substitution in the β-globin chain can cause sickle cell disease, which confers some protection against malaria as the parasites are less able to invade and replicate in sickled red blood cells. Thus, option D is the best explanation for the absence of infection in this group.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. G6PD deficiency is excluded, so the absence of infection in this subset cannot be attributed to that. Among the other options, only a glutamic acid substitution in the β-globin chain is associated with protection against severe malaria. It is thought that this substitution confers a structural disadvantage to the parasite, preventing invasion of the erythrocytes.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The fact that participants with G6PD deficiency are excluded implies that the cause of the absence of infection is related to a genetic factor. Among the options, only D, a glutamic acid substitution in the β-globin chain, is associated with protection against malaria infection. This is due to the fact that this substitution results in sickle cell hemoglobin, which confers resistance against malaria.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. Only option (D) relates to malaria infection. Glutamic acid substitution in the β-globin chain results in sickle cell trait, which provides some level of protection against malaria infection. Therefore, individuals with sickle cell trait may be included in the 9% without evidence of malaria infection.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The absence of infection in this subset of participants can be explained by the presence of a genetic mutation that results in a Glutamic acid substitution in the β-globin chain, leading to sickle cell trait. Sickle cell trait has been shown to provide some level of protection against malaria infection. Options A, B, and C are all unrelated to malaria resistance.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. G6PD enzyme deficiency is excluded from the study, which indicates that it is not a factor in the absence of infection. Option D refers to sickle cell anemia, which is more resistant to malaria infection due to the glutamic acid substitution in the β-globin chain of hemoglobin. An inherited defect in erythrocyte membrane ankyrin protein, a defective X-linked ALA synthase gene, and an inherited mutation affecting ribosome synthesis are not known to have a direct effect on malaria infection.
